Sam Childers.Action: Flashes a malicious smile and curses at the prison clerk.
His wife greets him with an uneasy smile, he responds with rough, non-tender sexual behavior.
Sits frozen, staring at his feet and workboots, appears lost and hesitant about his appearance and readiness.
Expresses insecurity about not having good shoes but accepts reassurance from Lynn, showing self-awareness but lack of confidence.
Attends church baptism service, looks uncomfortable and on edge, appearing uncertain about the situation and his place in it.
Lynn gives Sam a reserved smile of encouragement; he finds strength in her look and proceeds to be baptized despite hesitation.
Offers to continue helping construction work and learn new skills to stay employed despite uncertainty.
Is left alone, lost in thought after being told the crew is cut; Lynn joins him and they share a quiet moment.
Recognizes dangerous weather conditions quickly and takes immediate action to protect his family by arming himself and preparing shelter.
Shows decisiveness and prioritizes family safety under emotional stress.
Successfully completes the move into their new home, carries boxes, ensures all belongings are accounted for including the trunk contents.
Engages in playful banter with Lynn, showing relaxed and confident interpersonal interaction after hard work.
Engages playfully and intimately with Lynn, sharing laughter and a passionate kiss.
Listens attentively during the church service to a guest speaker discussing the needs of African Christian families.
Joking with Paige about tigers eating people, engaging playfully with children.
Expresses desire to go to Africa to help with school construction, showing concern for others.
Engages in construction work with volunteers in Uganda, actively contributing to mission work.
Examines Deng's weapon carefully and helps fix the problem with the magazine.
Hands weapon back to Deng after repairing it without hesitation.
Answers Deng's questions openly and with casual friendliness.
Keeps to himself while others socialize, choosing to read the Bible alone.
Attempts to connect with Deng by asking personal questions but respects Deng's reticent silence, intuitively recognizing his need for space.
Listens carefully to Deng waking him up about the LRA attack and promptly gets ready to respond by going to the village.
Allows children to sleep on the floor, makes sure they settle down before resting himself, showing patience and care.
Does not attempt to prevent the village attack or protect the children during the night; children vanish unexpectedly.
Drops to his knees and holds the dead boy, showing deep emotional resolve and making a silent vow to save children.
Is silent and aghast, staring at the horror and devastation with no immediate action.
Pauses at the airport door, quietly observing his family before joining them; manages complex emotions with a forced smile and controlled behavior.
Engages gently and playfully with his daughter Paige to ease tension and maintain family connection after returning from hardship.
Working hands-on with a crew to build a church, actively contributing.
Watching children play and engaging in friendly conversation with a former acquaintance and his daughter.
Shows willingness to minister to anyone seeking faith through the chapel he is building.
Breaks into crack house armed, confronts drug addicts to rescue Donnie.
Cares for Donnie during withdrawal, comforts him by saying 'God don't make trash'.
Organizes delivery of new boots to SPLA soldiers and personally inspects location despite safety warnings
Ignores Deng's warning about safety in the bush
On his knees, trying his best to soothe crying children despite feeling out of his depth.
Expresses clear commitment to the place and children despite dangers in the war zone.
Seeks someone reliable to run the orphanage and takes care to confirm her ability to care for children.
Quickly assesses the attack situation and recognizes the SPLA soldiers are scattered and vulnerable.
Makes a split-second decision to sprint across the compound under fire, implying decisive action in crisis.
Asks direct, relevant tactical questions to understand enemy numbers and friendly troop positions.
No apparent hesitation or confusion during the attack, showing confidence and presence of mind.
Recognizes the danger of scattered soldiers firing randomly and makes a split-second decision to sprint across the compound to intervene.
Commands Betty decisively to get the children to the church quickly, communicates effectively in both Arabic and English under stress.
Quickly retrieves an AK47 and ammunition from the storeroom without hesitation, showing preparedness and calm under pressure.
Assumes responsibility to cover the retreat by laying down suppression fire with the AK, enabling soldiers to fall back to safety.
Despite heavy enemy fire and a grenade explosion, continues to hold off rebels to protect others.
Organizes the women to put the children in the center of the chapel for protection during the attack.
Keeps firing back at rebels even when overwhelmed and retreating to buy time.
Commands soldiers to keep firing despite being outnumbered.
Fires his weapon while children are huddled in close proximity, risking their safety.
Leads and participates in rebuilding the orphanage compound, including physical labor and overseeing construction of protective fencing and facilities.
Shows attentiveness and respect by following Deng to observe the traditional cultural blessing by the camp women and children.
Stands quietly accepting a blessing from Betty, symbolizing a sincere connection to his African family and acceptance of responsibility for the children.
Eats lunch with SPLA soldiers and tries humorously to learn their language, showing an effort to connect and be friendly.
Rushing out quickly to help two injured, crying young boys brought by soldiers, showing responsiveness and care for vulnerable children.
Participates respectfully in local customs, listens attentively, and embraces his African family, showing cultural sensitivity and patient engagement.
Attempts to learn and speak the local language with humor and effort, demonstrating willingness to connect and adapt.
Responds quickly and decisively to urgent events by rushing out to assist injured children arriving in military trucks.
Recognizes the presence of children behind the truck and stops a teammate from firing an RPG, preventing potential friendly fire casualties.
Commands Marco to cover him while he advances under heavy fire, displaying tactical awareness and leadership.
Advances toward enemy position firing from the hip and reloads efficiently with another soldier under heavy gunfire.
Does not verbally respond to Deng's suggestion to go home, choosing to stay and fight.
Listens quietly to children singing an ancient lullaby, finds comfort in their voices, and lays peacefully in the dark
Accepts a gift discreetly from Bill intended for children he helps.
Looks around at extravagance with Lynn and Paige, sensing its scale without judgment.
Feeds hundreds of children and gives meals to anyone who shows up hungry.
Expresses commitment to fight for children despite personal danger.
Responds to Garang's advice with stubbornness and humor (refers to himself as stubborn as a mule).
Leads children in a playful surprise by having them cover their eyes and then reveal a new playground.
Leads children in a surprise unveiling of a new playground, coordinating others and managing a group of children confidently.
Sees frightened children hiding, approaches cautiously and attempts to rescue them with medical supplies.
Whistles to children to coax them out despite their fear.
Carefully examines injured children, assesses their health, prioritizes the worst off, communicates clearly with aid team and children.
Manages to load maximum children into SUV despite limited space, plans to return quickly to rescue more.
Orders soldiers to quickly leave after rescuing children, showing urgency and protective behavior.
Comes upon the burned bodies of children he left behind, deeply affected and emotionally shattered.
Silent and introspective after witnessing the tragic death of the children, indicating deep emotional impact and empathy.
Commands soldiers efficiently to prepare and leave quickly after rescue operation (e.g., 'Gas it up! We're leavin here in five!')
Uses GPS and situational awareness by noticing smoke and investigating the scene of the ambush
Fails to ensure all rescued children were accounted for and safe, resulting in thirteen children being left behind and burned alive
Stands silently and emotionally overwhelmed after discovering the deaths, indicating possible emotional impact but lack of immediate practical response
Is unable to answer the customs officer's question about why he was in Sudan, showing hesitation and lack of clarity.
Persists in applying for a short term loan despite being heavily leveraged and told the bank cannot help due to debt.
Persistent and strategic in convincing the bank manager to approve a loan by showing impactful evidence and framing his request clearly.
Uses emotional and graphic photographs to persuade the bank manager, demonstrating understanding of how to influence decisions effectively.
Insists on urgency and pushes aggressively but risks alienating the bank manager by not fully moderating his tone.
Goes completely still and frozen, visibly shocked and staring at the TV upon hearing of John Garang's death, seemingly absorbed and affected by the news.
Appears lost and distracted when his daughter Paige talks to him about weekend plans, not immediately engaging with her question.
Slams cabinet closed and walks away without explanation when questioned by Lynn
Sells family business without discussing it with Lynn, causing her distress
Prioritizes raising funds for the orphanage over personal/family assets
Sold the family business to fund a truck for the orphanage, prioritizing children over family's financial security.
Forgets his daughter's birthday and seems disconnected from family concerns.
Responds to Lynn's plea with anger and rejects spiritual comfort by saying 'Fuck the Lord'.
Acknowledges his pain and frustration about those kids but ultimately chooses to leave his family behind.
Moved past Deng without saying a word despite being greeted, eyes described as 'deserted'.
Sat isolated in a corner away from others, surrounded by a darkness metaphorically indicating emotional distance.
Flinched and reacted sharply when hot tea was accidentally spilled on him, then accidentally knocked William backward, causing silence in the room, and subsequently left the room.
Engages in a tender phone conversation with his daughter, expressing love and using a playful code to reconnect despite emotional distance.
Initiates playing soccer with the children even though awkward, breaking the tense atmosphere and bringing joy back to the camp.
His awkwardness at soccer hints a lack of skill in the activity itself but his persistence leads to positive social outcome.
Sits alone at the river's edge, reflecting peacefully and then performs a solemn baptismal act, signaling inner strength and spiritual conviction.
Engages in a quietly confident spiritual ritual that commands respect and praise from the onlookers, demonstrating emotional and spiritual competence.

Intuitively knows something is wrong about William’s disappearance, expresses worry, and immediately takes initiative to gather information by ordering someone to get a phone call to check if William has shown up at the base.
Stays behind with Deng to protect and care for 85 children despite danger, sending soldiers away for their safety.
Has rescued over 800 children from the LRA and runs an orphanage caring for more than 300 orphans and feeding over 1200 meals a day to villagers in need
Displays confidence and assertiveness immediately upon release from prison, flashing a malicious smile and using aggressive language toward the clerk.
Immerse in a chaotic, aggressive environment, seemingly unbothered or calm, indicating skill in navigating stressful or confrontational settings.
Greets his daughter Paige warmly and appreciates the welcome sign she and his mother made for him.
Engages in casual, slightly teasing conversation with Lynn about quitting smoking.
Checks on Lynn's work schedule and seems concerned about her staying for supper, indicating care for family cohesion.
Displayed nervousness/anxiety during the homecoming scene with family on edge and careful, but no overtly negative or dismissive behavior.
Engages with family members calmly and acknowledges homemade sign warmly.
Pressures Lynn about quitting smoking and work without apparent plan or follow-up.
Demonstrates sensitivity to family anxiety and tension in homecoming situation.
Threatens to hurt Mark if he isn't giving Lynn her time, shows protective instinct.
Uses harsh language and insults Lynn for quitting stripping to take another job.

Dismisses Daisy when she tries to intervene gently.
Laughs sarcastically at Lynn's claim of finding God and calls her a 'junkie stripper'.
Shoves Lynn back violently when she reaches for him.
Greets biker friends warmly and embraces Donnie as old friends.
Straddles the bike, kicks it to life, and peels out, showing confident and decisive physical action.
Interacts confidently with biker friends, greeting them and maintaining social bonds in a challenging environment.
Shoves Lynn back violently when she reaches for him, showing poor emotional control and potentially undermining interpersonal competence.
Dismisses Lynn's religious transformation with harsh words and skepticism, indicating closed-mindedness rather than thoughtful assessment.

Passes out on couch, withdrawn, daughter quietly leaves without speaking.
Stares at himself in the mirror with visible track marks, indicating struggle with addiction.
Uses methamphetamine despite being a parent and showing signs of severe physical and mental decline.
Recognizes the uncertain situation about his wife having 'found Jesus,' indicating some awareness of his environment.
Pulls a shotgun and forcefully breaks into a house occupied by strangers during a cold night, creating chaos and fear.
Pulls a shotgun from his jacket and storms into a dangerous drug house decisively and with confidence.
Pursues a fleeing suspect aggressively with a shotgun, threatening lethal violence, uses racial slur.
Chases down a fleeing suspect skillfully through the house, demonstrating tactical aggression and determination.
Uses a shotgun effectively to overpower the suspect in a high-stress situation.
Forces the suspect to reveal the location of contraband through intimidation and control.
Kicks a man toward a closet, threatens him with a shotgun barrel in his mouth, chambers a slug and almost kills him.
Celebrates a robbery with a friend, uses a racial slur about a defeated man, injects drugs and displays reckless behavior.
Notices a hitchhiker on a cold road but immediately mocks him instead of offering help.
Slams the butt of the shotgun into Shaved Head's face and forces the barrel into his mouth, demonstrating control and aggression during a robbery.

Immediately begins cooking cocaine and injecting Donnie after the robbery, showing recklessness and poor judgment.
Celebrates the robbery and drives recklessly under the influence with Donnie, indicating lack of self-control and impaired decision-making.
Greets the hitchhiker warmly with a friendly comment about the cold.
Refuses to take the hitchhiker to his requested destination, setting a clear boundary.
Reacts protectively and assertively when Donnie is threatened with a blade, attempting to prevent harm by accelerating the car.
Recognizes the threat of a blade pressed to Donnie's neck quickly and reacts by stomping on the gas pedal to accelerate away, showing quick thinking and decisive action under pressure.
Stabs the drifter multiple times in a violent struggle, then abandons the body and flees.
After the violent act, tries to clean himself and shows visible terror and fear; admits to his wife his fear and asks for help.
Suddenly jumps in the backseat and wrestles the drifter, disarming him and stabbing him multiple times, taking control of a life-threatening situation aggressively and decisively.
After the violent incident, he is covered in blood and frantically tries to clean himself up, showing signs of terror and fear, indicating emotional overwhelm despite physical capability.
Looks lost and insecure about his shoes, visibly vulnerable around Lynn.
Turns to Lynn and makes eye contact during the church altar call, showing openness and hesitance.
Gets up to go to the altar despite being hesitant and unsure, gaining strength from Lynn's encouragement.
Submits to baptism and receives it fully, showing commitment to a new start.
Offers to continue working, showing willingness to use his skills in drywalling, tiling, and some electrical work to remain employed.

Attempts to negotiate and sell his motorcycle at a used car lot, demonstrating knowledge of its custom value.
Reads patiently and explains difficult words to his daughter, showing care and ability to communicate effectively.
Comforts Paige by reassuring her they will be okay, holding his daughter close despite his own uncertainty.
Sits with an old friend, Donnie, at a bar and engages in conversation, showing willingness to reconnect.
Declines a drink at the bar, indicating possible self-control or distancing from negative influences.
Explains to his daughter in a simple, engaging way (about the rats) that demonstrates clarity and control over the story being told.
Sells his Harley because 'it's what I had to do,' showing an ability to make difficult decisions based on necessity.
Reassures his daughter they will be okay despite his own evident uncertainty, maintaining confidence outwardly.

Carries a shotgun presumably for protection in a crisis, indicating responsibility but also potential readiness for violence.

Stays outside the trailer in dangerous conditions, positioning himself to protect others while ensuring their safety first.

Encourages Paige to explore their new home, smiling and engaging with family warmly.
Shares playful, affectionate banter with Lynn, including teasing and reciprocal towel snapping.
Volunteers to go to Africa to help with building school roofs despite having ongoing responsibilities at home and other jobs, showing willingness to step up and take initiative.
Works alongside volunteers on the roof of a bombed out school in Uganda, engaging directly in constructive, hands-on work in a conflict zone.
Engages casually and confidently with armed SPLA guards, including questioning Deng about his affiliation, showing comfort and ability in tense, unfamiliar environments.
Diagnoses and fixes weapon malfunction (double-feed) skillfully by identifying the problem and adjusting the magazine base plate.
Admits he is not military and is 'not so good with bein told what to do,' showing self-awareness about his limitations with formal hierarchy.

Immediately helps aid workers transfer severely injured woman to a bed without hesitation.

Observes children arriving at night, showing concern and empathy about their situation.

Observes the situation carefully and thoughtfully, noting the large number of children and the dangers they face.
Approaches and encourages children huddled on the street to come inside for shelter despite limited space.
Insists on helping the children he can gather instead of walking away after realizing he can't help all.

Physically arranges cots and reorganizes the small hotel room to create more space for the children to rest.
Attempts to gather too many children initially but accepts the limitation when informed, showing realistic judgment.

Notices the children’s fear and presence, particularly the boy in green shorts and his sister, showing awareness and concern.

Does not share his deeper feelings when Lynn asks if he is okay, though she senses more; he refrains from opening up and she does not push.

Engages in social interaction confidently and clearly communicates his ministry intentions to a casual acquaintance.

Is actively fixing a leaking pipe in the church moments before service, showing hands-on problem solving and responsibility.

Insists on moving into an unsafe area despite Deng's warning, showing disregard for caution that could potentially endanger others.

Dismisses local administrator's advice about safety and logistical concerns, possibly underestimating risks.
Recognizes his own limitations in caring for the children and immediately seeks competent help to run the orphanage.

Engages Deng in a sincere conversation about belief and God, gently encourages hope.

Sweeps his AK across the compound defending the children and Betty amidst heavy gunfire.
Stares at the burned remains of the orphanage, appearing empty, alone, and defeated.
Sweeps his AK across the compound, actively defending the chapel and the children amid heavy gunfire.

Communicates honestly and calmly over the phone after the attack, indicating emotional control despite defeat.
Responds to Lynn's call despite emotional pain, listens and finds strength to continue his mission.
Shows resignation and heartache in his voice, indicating struggle with emotional burden.

Organizes and oversees the rebuilding of the orphanage compound, including strengthening its security with a chainlink fence and constructing new buildings such as dorms, an infirmary, a mess hall, and barracks.

Sits calmly in the office using communication tools like short-wave radio and satellite phone, showing usage of technical resources for administrative purposes.

Pushes a couple of smaller children on the swingset, helping them play.

Dismisses additional military protection, showing trust and confidence in his own ability rather than being fearful or demanding.
Notices William sitting alone and not playing, indicating attentiveness and concern for a child's emotional state.

Realizes William doesn't understand English and sits silently, reflecting deeply on his own fears and past.
Displays self-awareness about his past and current fears, which indicates emotional intelligence but also a self-doubt.
Stops short of taking further action to bridge the communication gap or help William communicate, instead turning inward.
Orders to keep a potential witness safe and still despite danger.
Proactively organizes a team to suppress sniper fire to enable his movement to safety.
Kills sniper to protect others and moves with team to rescue chained children.
Rolls onto his stomach and carefully slides the rifle barrel between rocks to spot the sniper, showing tactical positioning.

Successfully takes out the sniper with a precise shot, displaying marksmanship and tactical efficiency.

Getting angry and confrontational when accused of being a mercenary rather than a humanitarian.
Shares the videocassette screen with orphaned children, allowing them to see and enjoy it together.
Experiences heartache and melancholy over the distance from his family and their innocence.
Sits in the passenger seat while a young SPLA soldier drives through a dangerous area at night, indicating trust in others' skills and situational awareness.
Does not take the wheel himself despite being the mission lead, potentially indicating delegation or lack of direct control at that moment.
Leads aggressive armed attack on rebel convoy, engaging in lethal firefight.
Commands his men to engage immediately under heavy fire and participates actively in the firefight, showing leadership and tactical aggression.
Leans out of the moving truck firing continuously while under return fire, effectively contributing to the suppression of enemies and enabling the convoy to be stopped.
Commands his men to kill rebels and then immediately shifts focus to rescuing terrified, emaciated children tied up in a transport truck.
Shows concern for the children’s wellbeing, carefully instructing to gently place the children together and prioritizing those unlikely to survive.
Reaches out with a gentle reassurance to a frightened little girl, attempting to calm her fear.
Leads a successful ambush against rebels, decisively neutralizing them.
Quickly assesses the damaged truck and commands the use of a spotlight to locate and rescue children.
Makes a prompt decision to take the most vulnerable children first, showing prioritization and clear thinking under pressure.
Reaches out to a frightened child calmly, attempting to build trust.
Gently examines injured children, tenderly runs hands over their broken, starved bodies, prioritizes those worse off.
Reassures children he will return soon and instructs them to hide until he comes back, showing care for their safety and emotional state.
Quietly stands in line at customs, cut-off from the life around him, unable to answer the customs officer's probing question.
Allows Donnie, who is strung out, to greet him warmly with a smile and friendly words, not reacting negatively to Donnie's state.
Discusses a short term loan with the bank manager, persistently seeking help despite financial difficulties; humbly accepts the constraints imposed by the bank.
Shows gruesome photos of abused children to the bank manager to emphasize the urgent need for a loan to save children.
Pushes aggressively and insists the bank manager approve the loan despite his discomfort.
Speaks passionately about fighting evil and urges congregation to wake up and take action against injustice.
Acts with intense rage and harsh tone, slamming desk and shouting.
Delivers a powerful, passionate sermon that energizes and motivates the congregation, demonstrating strong oratory skills and leadership presence.
Loses temper and slams the desk during conversation with bank manager.
Goes completely still and frozen, shocked upon hearing news of John Garang's death, momentarily losing focus and not responding to his daughter's conversation.
Refuses to rent a limo for daughter Paige's formal with harsh language and anger.
Snaps at family members repeatedly, shouting and threatening physical punishment to daughter Paige.
Expresses frustration about financial responsibility to feed family but reacts with hostility rather than calm explanation.
Fails to acknowledge/diffuse growing emotional tension, escalating conflict instead.
Firmly denies spending money on a limo, showing control over household finances and decisiveness.
Becomes uncontrollably angry, yells at family members, and threatens physical violence.
Ignores attempts at calm by others, escalating tension unnecessarily.
Threatens Donnie with violence and insults him harshly, causing emotional pain to others in the room.
Politely tries to disengage from the biker by requesting to be left alone, avoiding confrontation.
Holds his ground firmly during a heated confrontation with Donnie, clearly setting boundaries and asserting authority, leading to Donnie's retreat.
Chooses to quietly sit alone and decline engaging with the antagonistic biker group despite their provocation.
Allows the biker to verbally abuse him with racial slurs without escalating the situation aggressively or engaging further.
Head-butts the Biker after racist verbal attack and fights violently to defend himself.
Sits silently in Lynn's car while she expresses her concern and emotions about his dangerous path and its impact on family.
Does not answer Donnie's call, hesitating to engage.
Head-butts the Biker aggressively and takes down multiple attackers in a violent brawl.
Sits silently without responding to Lynn's emotional plea, showing passivity in an important relational moment.
Does not answer Donnie's vibrating phone call, choosing omission over engagement.
Attempts to speak at Donnie's funeral but stops and walks away without delivering a comforting message.
Stands before the congregation at a funeral but is unable to deliver a speech, walks away silently instead of addressing the crowd.
Sells his business quickly to get funds for the orphanage, takes decisive action in a difficult situation.
Avoids explaining his actions to Lynn and rushes through emotionally charged moments without clear communication.
Sells the family business impulsively to buy a new truck for the orphanage, neglecting financial stability and family needs.
Forgets his own daughter's birthday combination, showing a lack of attention to personal important details.
Grabs cash from the vault to fund his cause despite warnings of losing house and church, demonstrating reckless decision-making.
Recognizes the conflicts and consequences of his choices, visibly weighing his decisions, indicating some internal reflection about his actions.
Prioritizes fighting for the children abroad over his family's wellbeing, showing misaligned priorities but persistence towards his mission.
Responds to greeting with silence and moves past without acknowledgment, showing emotional disconnect.
Sits isolated from group, demonstrates physical flinch and accidentally knocks a person down during a tense moment.
Immediately leaves the room after the incident without addressing the disruption or calming the situation.
Shoots multiple rebels decisively to protect Agnete and others.
Displays a 'killer's thousand-yard stare', 'barely human' and 'more like a machine than a man' in a violent moment.
Leads a well-coordinated, intense gunfire assault on the rebels, effectively neutralizing the threat quickly.
Exhibits a cold, machine-like killing focus with a thousand-yard stare during combat, suggesting high mental preparation for violence.
Kills the rebel leader decisively to end the threat.
Sits alone, lost and soul worn thin, tears in his eyes, distraught over the suffering of children and loss of friend.
Turns away and rejects Deng's offer of help, stating 'I don't need your help.'
Despite his despair and holding a gun to his head, he allows William to comfort him and embraces him, showing vulnerability and openness to connection.
Initially frozen and silent when struggling with internal pain, not rejecting William's presence but accepting his gentle comfort.
Communicates calmly and tenderly with his daughter over the satellite phone despite harsh conditions, showing emotional control and presence of mind.
Uses a private, personal code with his daughter to maintain connection and morale, demonstrating thoughtful emotional intelligence and relational skill.
Expresses vulnerability and emotional difficulty in words unsaid during the phone call, indicating awareness of his emotions but possibly limited verbal coping strategies.
Comes into the courtyard and initiates playing soccer alone, drawing the children in and bringing laughter and joy back to the camp.
Sits quietly by the riverbank observing and appreciating the beauty around him and the women singing while working.
Performs a baptism-like ritual in the river, demonstrating spiritual sincerity and vulnerability.
Shows visible worry and concern when William is missing, intuitively sensing something is wrong.
Decides to go look for William after hearing he is missing.
Leads a tactical pursuit to intercept LRA convoy transporting shackled children, actively engaging in a firefight to stop them.
Leads a violent attack against LRA rebels threatening the area, providing covering fire to his men and driving the rebels off.

Leads a tactical ambush using trucks, coordinates flanking fire to overwhelm the enemy convoy, takes precise RPG shots, provides covering fire for charges and commands cease fire to end the battle efficiently.
Urgently commands soldiers to unload and cut loose 100 children shackled and crammed in transport trucks, showing immediate concern for their safety and well-being.
Stands momentarily lost in indecision, looking into the children's eyes before decisively acting to save them.
Methodically assesses the health of the children, separating the worse off from the others to give proper care.
Provides covering fire skillfully to protect others and successfully disperses enemies.
Quickly directs soldiers to unload and cut loose the children from the transport trucks.
Assesses the children's health effectively and organizes groups to prioritize the weaker children for transport.
Moment of hesitation and indecision standing and staring at the children before taking action.
Recovers decisively after hesitation, immediately orders to get children out and lines them up for rescue.
Systematically scavenges dead enemies' weapons and ammo, arming his team efficiently.
Directs soldiers to climb on the roof and keep watch for potential threats on the road.
Decides to stay behind with Deng and the children while soldiers retreat, showing confidence and readiness to face danger.
